data.title: Adding Discard Hints Vertex/IndexBuffer (TEST ME!)
data.body:
This pull adds the "discard hint" trick to the VertexBuffer and IndexBuffer SetData() calls.

You should see an improvement in framerate if you are using a DynamicVertexBuffer and/or DynamicIndexBuffer which updates every frame passing the SetDataOptions.Discard flag to SetData().

In our case we saw a 40% improvement in frame rate on iOS.  

Please test it if you use Discard on your iOS and Android games.

data.title: Fixed the sampler state on sprite batches
data.body:
This is somewhat patchy, but I don't understand why the texture and the sampler state are not activated deeper down (when applying the fragment shader), and assume there is a good reason for it. 
Right now at least, the sampler states work for sprite batches.

data.title: Linux sound pause/resume issue
GL DrawPrimXXX() Optimization (PLEASE TEST!)
data.body:
This pull request converts the GraphicsDevice.DrawUserXXX() methods to render directly from pinned index and vertex arrays.

This optimization is based on [feedback from the Infinite Flight team](https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/pull/761#issuecomment-8482636) and reports of [performance problems with SpriteBatch](https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/765).

Please test it and let me know how it performs compared to Develop3D.

data.body:

Using my branch which was last updated on sept 7, everthing is fine:

data.title: Touch Fix
data.body:
Touch fixes for issue reported in pull...

https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/pull/758

The promotion of touch locations to a "moved" state when no new event comes thru would loose the previous state information.

Only tested on Win8 so far.

data.title: Deferred GL RenderState and Shader API
data.body:
First off I apologize for this pull request getting this big...  I may try to cherry pick out some things and submit them separately.  For now I just needed to get this out to the for review.

This merge contains two main features...
### Deferred GL RenderState

The GL code has always immediately applied render state.  Which meant that if you did this...

```
device.BlendState = BlendState.Opaque;
device.BlendState = BlendState.Additive;
device.BlendState = BlendState.Opaque;
```

... or something similar you would get unnecessary render state changes.  Of course you would not do this sort of thing on purpose, but things like this happen all the time in complex rendering code.

What this code change does is defer all application of GL state until one of the GraphicsDevice.Draw() methods are called.  At draw time we know exactly the final state to be set.... which results in a perfect application of render state with no possibility of redundant changes.

You will see a performance improvement in just about any game.
### Shader API

XNA exposes an Effect system to the user... you can seemingly only assign one Effect at a time... but under the hood XNA uses shaders.  

This is a feature that is exploited by the [XNA Bloom Postprocess sample](http://xbox.create.msdn.com/en-US/education/catalog/sample/bloom).  The sample renders a full screen quad using SpriteBatch and custom Effect without a vertex shader.  Often this functionality is erroneously attributed to a magical "default shader"... there is no such thing.

What is really happening under the hood is much simpler.  SpriteBatch first assigns its own SpriteEffect which has a vertex and pixel shader.  After it does that it applies the custom Effect you provided it.  If your custom Effect happens to only have a pixel shader then you end up with a mix...  the vertex shader from SpriteEffect and your pixel shader.

This is pull request adds a Shader API to MonoGame... for now all marked as internal.  The Effect system then sets the vertex and pixel Shader individually on the GraphicsDevice along with ConstantBuffers.  Then at Draw() time the right GL shader program is looked up from a cache, applied to the GL context, and the constant buffers update the uniforms.

This change also means 2MGFX allows you to create effects with only a pixel or vertex shader now.
### TEST ME!

This code so far has been tested with our game and a few sample apps on iOS and Windows 8.  

We need others to test their games on it.

We need people to test it on all the other platforms... Linux, MacOS, Android, etc.

data.title: Added Windows 8 support for launching by protocol handler
data.body:
Xbox LIVE on Windows requires support for launching by protocol handler.  Add protocol URI to LaunchParameters.  URI gets split into schema (key) and path (value).
Re-worked population of Game.LaunchParameters to work the same as XNA 4 on Windows.
- Parameters can optionally start with a forward slash.
- Keys can be separated from values by a colon.
- Double quotes can be used to enclose spaces.

data.title: Stretched images after start the game in portrait mode
data.body:
I have a small project that only draws a small circle (60px of radius) on the screen.

If i start the game on the simulator in landscape mode, everything works fine. I can change the orientation from landscape to portrait mode, and vice versa, without problems. 

The problem happens if I start the game in portrait mode. The circle is not shown as a circle, but as an ellipse and never goes back to normal.

[Expected]

The circle should appears like a circle. (radius = 60px)

[Result]

The circle appears like an ellipse.

data.title: Android fixes - touch and orientation handling
data.body:
- Fixes an issue with Android touch coordinates so the scaling is now handled in the new TouchPanel.
- Removed the concept of disabling touch input during a device orientation change. This was flakey as it was quite possible to trigger an orientation change but not get the SurfaceChanged event after.
- Improved ResetClientBounds so it keeps the PresentationParamters buffer size in sync
- Called ResetClientBounds at startup to ensure the Viewport is correctly offset. When the user specifies non-device aspect ratios, ResetClientCounds scales and offsets to handle this. It uses the Viewport offset values, which is not strictly speaking correct (should really be a render target instead), but at least now the Viewport offset value is correct at startup. Previously it would only be correct after an orientation change!.

data.title: Texture2D.FromStream not implemented for Windows 8 (Metro)
data.body: Currently this method is not implemented forcing users to use the XNB file format instead of loading from PNG files.

data.title: Remove GraphicsDeviceCapabilities class
data.body: This class was removed in XNA Framework 4.0 when the Reach and HiDef graphics profiles were added.  Our class was never implemented in any case.

data.title: Added two more classes to Content Pipeline
data.body: Completed stub implementation of the AudioContent and SongProcessor classes.

data.title: Added a call to UnregisterReceiver
data.body: Added a call to UnregisterReceiver in the OnDestroy of the AndroidGameActivity

data.title: Visual Studio 2010 project template for Android.
data.body: Also made the project description and assembly info consistent among the VS2010 templates.

data.title: Rework Android Shutdown sequence
data.body:
The android shutdown sequence was not calling OnDestroy as the Activity was not being closed correctly. 
This PR fixes that. when calling Game.Exit the correct activity shutdown sequence is followed.

data.title: Fixed VertexPosition2ColorTexture for Win8
data.body:
This fixes a bug exposed by pull request...

https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/pull/748

VertexPosition2ColorTexture is used by SpriteBatch to remove the Z coordinate from the vertex format and save 4 bytes per-vertex.  (Note: this may or may not be a win performance wise)

It had a bad VertexDeclaration...

 new VertexElement(8, VertexElementFormat.Byte4, VertexElementUsage.Color, 0), 

... Byte4 is an unnormalized format which lead to color overflow in the shader and failed rendering on DX.  in GL we are assuming all VertexElementUsage.Color types are normalized... this may or may not be a bug as well.

Tested on Windows 8 and Windows GL.  Should have no harmful effect on any other platform.

data.title: Get rename PlayStation Suite to PlayStation Mobile, and make sure everything compiles with latest v0.99.11
Fix For "Failed to make context current."
data.body:
This is a fix for the OpenTK GraphicsContextException "Failed to make context current. Error: 170" that has been happening lately.

Seems like it was added because of this issue...

  https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/596

So the change to call...

`Threading.BackgroundContext.MakeCurrent( Threading.WindowInfo );`

... on all platforms broke threaded content loading on Windows.

The explanation from the OpenTK site is that you cannot make a context current on two different threads...

http://www.opentk.com/node/1714

... by making it current on the foreground thread that makes it unable to be made current on the background thread.  There is really no reason to make it current in the foreground thread... Sly even mentioned that...

"It would appear that at the time the first SpriteBatch is created, the main
thread does not have the main context set as current.  Elisee's work-around
is not really the correct way to do it as this is making the secondary
context current on the UI thread."

In my commit here I've removed the line.

I suggest we find the real bug with Linux not having the main GL context active.

data.title: Rework of SpriteBatcher
data.body:
This pull request includes a rework on the SpriteBatcher to use the GraphicsDevice.UserDrawPrimitives call rather than having its own calls to OpenGL or DirectX. It means we get rid of a whole load of #ifdef code in this file and the SpriteBatchItem.

It also adds the DynamicSoundEffectInstance class shell and some modifications to the SoundEffectInstance which will hopefully let us support the DynamicSoundEffect.

There is also a fix for the RenderTarget Viewport issue and the ScissorRectangle issue, that code came from codeplex.

The Android project changes are because of the latest verison of Mono for Android.

I dont know why I'm getting diffs on the Content Pipeline classes, its probably a hang back to the problems I had with git when merging in the latest code. If you know how I can fix this let me know (I have all the correct settings in the git global config).

data.title: Accelerometer
data.body:
I rewrote the accelerometer to follow the MSDN standard. The old accelerometer implementation was not working properly, so I put a "light" version of the original one in MonoGame.
I would recommend rewriting all accelerometers like this.

data.title: [iOS] Prepare for MonoTouch 5.4
data.body:
A new version of monotouch is about to go stable. It includes cross-thread UI checks, which currently produces several exceptions in debug mode to help identify unsafe code.
More info:
http://docs.xamarin.com/ios/releases/MonoTouch_5/MonoTouch_5.4

data.title: Touch Refactor
data.body:
This pull request consists of a major refactor of TouchPanel to simply over complicated gesture logic and fix many different inconsistencies with MS XNA.

It was based on Nezz's changes to TouchPanel from pull request...

https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/pull/717

So far it has been tested on iOS, Android, and Windows 8.

If you have a game using develop3d it would be extremely helpful for you to test this branch before it is merged.

data.body:
Steve proposed this fix: https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/pull/691#issuecomment-8243658

I've tested on iOS, Mac and Android. I can't test for WinRT so I haven't modified it's code path. If someone wants to test that and it works, feel free to make a PR and close this one.

data.title: OpenTK.Graphics.GraphicsContextException: Failed to make context current
data.body:
With the latest code, I've started getting 'OpenTK.Graphics.GraphicsContextException: Failed to make context current' exceptions.
Before I did not experience these issues.

Any idea what this means?

```
Error: Failed to make context current.OpenTK.Graphics.GraphicsContextException: Failed to make context current.
  at OpenTK.Platform.X11.X11GLContext.MakeCurrent (IWindowInfo window) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
  at OpenTK.Graphics.GraphicsContext.MakeCurrent (IWindowInfo window) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Threading.BlockOnUIThread (System.Action action) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Texture2D..ctor (Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.GraphicsDevice graphicsDevice, Int32 width, Int32 height, Boolean mipmap, SurfaceFormat format, Boolean renderTarget) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Texture2D..ctor (Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.GraphicsDevice graphicsDevice, Int32 width, Int32 height, Boolean mipmap, SurfaceFormat format) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.Texture2DReader.Read (Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.ContentReader reader, Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Texture2D existingInstance) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.ContentTypeReader`1[Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Texture2D].Read (Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.ContentReader input, System.Object existingInstance) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.ContentReader.ReadObject[Texture2D] () [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.SpriteFontReader.Read (Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.ContentReader input, Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SpriteFont existingInstance) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.ContentTypeReader`1[Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SpriteFont].Read (Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.ContentReader input, System.Object existingInstance) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.ContentReader.ReadObject[SpriteFont] () [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.ContentReader.ReadAsset[SpriteFont] () [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.ContentManager.ReadAsset[SpriteFont] (System.String assetName, System.Action`1 recordDisposableObject) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.ContentManager.Load[SpriteFont] (System.String assetName) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
```

I am not getting these issues with XNA

data.title: iOS - IAsyncResult from BeginShowMessageBox completed too early
